reviewText:
Rochard is a sci-fi platform game which was initially released on the PlayStation 3 network in 2011, but was eventually ported to he PC later in that year.  The game  revolves around taking control of gravity, and using the gravity gun called the G-Lifter. This is used to manipulate objects around the levels.  This game has it all, increasingly challenging environmental puzzles, action, a rich story line and plenty of humor.

The game play is a two dimensional side scrolling platformer that takes place in three dimensional scenes. You work your way through the environments completing a series of puzzles and combat encounters.  You are able to change the gravity in the room very easily at just the press of a button. All of the puzzles are easy enough for you to not get stuck on them for ages, but hard enough so that you can't just stroll into a room and instantly be able to figure it out. It hits the sweet spot just right.

The graphical fidelity is very pleasing, it has a nice art style which works well with this type of game. All of the character models look well polished and has brilliant animation. The voice acting is also top notch here too, something a fair few games manage to fall down on.

While the single player story mode took me about five hours to complete; I felt as if it managed to fulfill its potential in that time. There is also some DLC available for a very cheap price which includes four new challenging puzzle levels. Granted there is more of an emphasis on the puzzle solving as apposed to the combat, but even for the most experienced puzzle platforming players you'll find them difficult. I did have to check out the walkthrough because I was stumped at times.

This is a really well ported game, I didn't have any technical problems, you are able to play in higher resolutions and the game does work with the keyboard and mouse, however it is highly recommended you use a controller with these types of games.

I would recommend Rochard to people who really enjoy the puzzle platforming genre, people expecting an action packed side scrolling shooter will probably not find the thrill they are looking for. But if you want a couple hours of figuring out puzzles in a sci-fi environment, you may as well try Rochard

reviewText:
Rochard is a physics puzzle platformer, which came out a few years ago, long before the current glut of physics puzzle platformers. In retrospect, Rochard is obviously an older game with many design flaws that were the result of not being able to learn the mistakes of other titles in the genre.

First of all, the game's positives: Rochard has fairly good graphics and 90s cartoon art style. The protagonist is not a faceless muscular commando, but a working stiff with a potbelly and some personality. The supporting characters are similarly varied, and the entire cast has decent voice acting. The writing is nothing special, but the style of story does fit well with the cartoony art aesthetic, though any plot twists are obvious from a mile away.

The problems with the game are that it focuses on both combat and puzzle solving, but does neither very well. Combat is done using a combination Gravity Gun/Laser Blaster against mercernaries or bots. Enemy AI is simplistic, reminiscent of very early console platformers. There's very little challenge in that area, so you would expect something more from the puzzle department. Unfortunately, that is not the case, as puzzles are equally simplistic, never reaching the level of mind-bending challenge that a dedicated puzzle game like Portal or The Swapper provides. So what's left? Nothing. No high score mechanic, and no exploration. There's a barebones badly executed attempt at Metroidvania elements for collectables which forces some backtracking, but that's not at all enjoyable due to lack of fast movement abilities, and lack of enjoyable combat.

All in all, Rochard is simply less than the sum of its parts.

reviewText:
Rochard never gained enough traction because of its small marketing efforts and smaller demographic, which is a shame because it's the quintessential small, charming indie puzzle platformer game with personality and care. This was one of the earliest games to utilize the Unity Engine. It benefits from it, and will feel current for many years.

Highlights
Without its charming indie feel and homely 80s personality Rochard would've been just another, slightly above average, platformer. But some really symbiotic design and gameplay elements elevate this to something a little better than the rest.

* Great characters that didn't even need to have personality but were given tons
* Incredible voice acting for a game of this budget
* Above average lighting and background design
* Fairly challenging at times, brain required
* A good, 80s-feel soundtrack

MistakesPlatformers are relatively simple in their design and tend to need combinations of good mechanics, unique or useful collectibles or alternative ways of solving things. Rochard suffers from a lack of these and often feels bland and samey.

* Very annoying AI and level manipulation at time, repeating the same mistake a few times is jarring when it's the game engines' fault
* Mechanics, despite working well, feel repetitive after so long
* Bland and slow paced at times

RecommendationsRochard clocks in at 6 hours play time and doesn't have much re-playability, but it's relatively cheap; £7.99/8.99€/$9.99 at the time of review and it goes on sale for up to -90% regularly on Steam, so is definitely a buy at less than 1 Buck, Quid or Euro. It's available on mobile and a ton of other platforms and comes up in bundles, so look out for it being cheaper somewhere else if you care about a few cents.

* The Hard Times DLC is pretty difficult and challenging, and only adds challenge maps. It's probably only worth considering buying after completing the full game.
* The voice of John Rochard is played by Jon St. John ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jon_St._John ), who also helped voice elements of Duke Nukem, Dota 2, Sonic Adventures, Guild Wars 2 and Amnesia.

reviewText:
It's a very good title if you like physics-based mechanics, but the game doesn't exactly involve a lot of physics puzzles. For me, that was a good thing, because I am personally not a huge fan of pure physics puzzles games. They tend to feel kind of shallow.

Rochard's two biggest uses of physics are A) Catapaulting heavy objects on top of enemies to kill them, and B) a wide variety of anti-gravity navigation situations.

Enemies can be shot directly. Or you can throw heavy crates on top of them. Or---when applicable---you can break/pull the floor out from underneath them so that they fall to their death or land in an electric field. You can hold a crate in front of you at such an angle that enemy laser fire is deflected off the crate and ricochets into other enemies (but this requires a little bit of luck and is hard to execute intentionally). You can use your gravity gun to redirect mounted lasers into enemies to kill them. Later in the game, just like Half-Life 2, you can power up the grav gun to pick up the enemies themselves and throw them. You also receive three grenade types throught the game: a grenade that bounces and has a timed explosion, a grenade that sticks to a surface and has a detonated explosion, and a grenade that sticks to a surface and causes whatever it's touching to float into the air. Experimenting with all the different ways to kill enemies is one of the funnest aspects of the game, and successfully killing them with crates or other environmental hazards does not get old.

reviewText:
A very entertaining little platform game that introduces a nice gravity-gun idea that has combines some action and puzzle elements.
While the puzzle elements aren't all that complex during the campaign, I still found them very nice.  The gradual enhancements introduced to the gravity gun throughout the game made for some nice pacing and added variety to the puzzles and gameplay.  Early on your gun is only able to lift and move light crates, but later you add the ability to throw crates, then able to affect gravity (strong or weak), then to fire it as a blaster, then to also lob grenades (and later different types of grenades), to later be able to support yourself from a suspended crate or handle, etc.  Very cool!  And they introduced them slow enough you could utilize and enjoy the new skill on a number of levels before introducing something new.

The Good:+ Very well done platform game
+ Novel idea with the gun to pick up, move and throw objects and affect gravity.
+ Nice graphics, animations, and art style
+ Entertaining story
+ Good number of levels.  To me the campaign lasted just over 6 hours.  (The Hard Times DLC added another ~1.8 hours)

The OK:~ Some say the puzzles are on the easy side, but I enjoyed them all the same.  (Go for the Hard Times DLC which are 4 levels that are much more difficult if you like challenges)

The Bad:- Nothing comes to mind.

Overall:  I thought over this was a very well done platform game, which to me stands out better than most.  8 out of 10.

I was pleasantly surprised by this game. It created little fanfare when it was released, and it hasn't gotten much publicity on Steam since, but it's a solid and entertaining little physics platformer.

It starts off a little slow, with Rochard's abilities being quite limited, and the rock blaster barely able to fire 3 bolts in a row. By the end of the game, though, you will be zipping around in low gravity, blasting turrets in mid-air, while launching sticky bombs at enemies, and throwing their corpses at their friends. In the beginning, it might seem like combat is limited, but sweet merciful crap does it get fun by the end or what.

The music is very well-done, although unfortunately you rarely ever hear it. The song that plays in the casino is amazing, and it made me glad that I bought the soundtrack version. The graphics are also well done, using the Unity engine, although some of the texture work is a little shoddy.

The puzzles are also top-notch. There were only a few that genuinely stumped me for a while, but they all at least require thought and a little bit of planning. Sometimes I evem got the feeling that my solution was not the one the developers intended, and I love when I'm able to do that.

Controls on the 360 gamepad are solid as well, for the most part. There were a few tricky sections where I needed to aim the right analog stick to the right while pressing A and holding down LT, though, which required a little digital (get it? fingers) acrobatics. I didn't have any real issues with it, but I could see it being a problem for some others. I imagine keyboard and mouse controls would work just as well, if not better, but this game seemed to scream 360 CONTOLLER" to me.

reviewText:
OK. Now. I have to say, I'm taken by this game.

Imagine if you will, a fat, hairy, red neck (no offence meant BTW) trucker/miner, in space, billions of miles from Earth, and people are trying to kill him. This miner though, has brains and brawn, and a gravity gun that can shoot rocks to smithereens and a grenade launch capability.

You'll be close to Rochard.

I love the fact you have one handheld that not only covers a normal gun, grenade launcher, but also a gravity gun. You can utilise the items around you, using the gravity gun (normally cargo boxes) to either jump on, kill bad guys, duck under.. well, you get the idea?

You can also control gravity, once you've located the gravity generators. Which makes for some fun light weight mahem. =) And some very high jumps.

The graphics are smooth, bright, cartoony, and enjoyable to watch, the background has a nice movement about it when you're booling about, giving it a sense of depth and even the story line is alright, but definitely not to be taken seriously.

The dialogue can be staid at times, and funny at others. Again, just don't take it too seriously.

I have to admit, there's been a couple of times when I've had to scratch my head and actually think about how to solve a problem. Moving fuses though certain types of electric fields, or trying to avoid a large laser. Some of the puzzles are time based, like jumping from moving platform to moving platform, and I can imagine some people loosing their rag very easily.

I've found, personally, that playing with mouse/keyboard much easier than a gamepad, as I feel I have more control with the mouse to move the gun about, but each player has their preferences overall.

Musically, it's nice to listen to. The casino music is brilliant, and I wish I'd splashed out and got the soundtrack too, but, NVM.

Overall, I'm glad I bought it, and I'm pretty sure you would too.

10/10 in my books.

reviewText:
Rochard is a physics platformer, and quite a good one at that.  It's definitely not the longest game out there, but the length is quite reasonable for the price.

The game mechanics focus around your G-Lifter, which combines a gravity gun, laser rifle, and grenade launcher into one device as well as gravity manipulation.  You will unlock grenade types as you progress through the game as well as new abilities for the G-Lifter.  The pacing is quite good and new mechanics are introduced at regular intervals.

None of the puzzles are terribly complicated and shouldn't take much thought to complete.  Finding secrets requires a bit more thought and use of advanced game mechanics but are all still pretty easy.  It's definitely not as much of a thinking game as other puzzle platformers like Portal.  That said, it's still quite enjoyable, and I think the game could easily become frustrating if the puzzles were made too difficult.

On the negative side, the voice acting is terrible.  It's not Two Worlds bad, but it's close.  The writing isn't much better, but at least the story is decent.

The DLC is a short series of challenge rooms and much more of a challenge than the puzzles in the main game.  While very short it is quite enjoyable and satisfying to make it through them, especially if you can manage to do it without dying.

If you like puzzle platformers or physics platformers, you should play this game!

reviewText: I like this game a whole bunch.  Rochard is a 2D physics-based puzzle-solving and combat game.  Nothing it's doing is entirely novel, but gameplay feels good and does a good job of co-opting Half-Life 2's gravity gun while mixing it with variable environmental gravity levels.  The weapons that you eventually acquire are satisfying, but combat is at its best when you use objects and enemies' weapons against them instead of attacking directly.  Likewise, puzzles are fairly straightforward but will sometimes surprise you.  There are a fair few very memorable moments throughout the game.\n\nThe whole experience  is imbued with some pretty decent personality and humor; you've seen better characters and more comical narratives, but what's here certainly helps the game to stand out.  It's also filled with beautiful, atmospheric environments and scored with a gorgeous and diverse soundtrack.  Rochard is pretty delightful for its entire 6-odd hours; I definitely recommend it.

reviewText:
Ever heard of this game? I hadn't. It was in my Steam list because I apparently got it from Humble Bundle 6. Well it looked like an action-y physics puzzle platformer (think Trine) and I like that kind of thing so I went ahead and launched it.  I'm glad I did!

The game was enjoyable, accessible and pretty unique, mostly because there aren't a lot of entries in this genre. Despite the fact that the game flew under my radar, I found the art, effects and voice acting to be pretty top-notch for a game of this type. It's clear that the team loved about this game. It was short-ish, which is expected. About 6 hours. And the story has a fairly unique premise, but it gets kinda mucked up with some really stupid cliches. Despite that, I found Rochard himself to be the game's most lovable character. A rotund, twangy and kind space-miner.

The game spends most of its time allowing you to use a Half-Life 2 style Gravity Gun in many of the same ways Half-Life 2 does, but with a few twists, such as pairing that concept with low-gravity, and solving larger-scale platforming puzzles. It's shameless, but still different.

There's a lot of things that don't fit together with the game's theme... like how many people you actually end up just gunning down as cartoony cannon fodder... and the stupid native american mysticism subplot. Regardless of my complaints, I have nothing against Rochard and genuinely enjoyed my time with it.

It was the Space Debris music in the trailer that sold this game to me. So having just bought the Soundtrack Edition of the game, I listened through the soundtrack first before playing the game. Rochard is a light-hearted physics-based side scroller set in a future-grunge world of space mining. Playing as John Rochard, you use your grapple gun and anti-grav physics to overcome environmental obstacles and enemies.

The production of Rochard is top-notch and the physics superbly done. The game starts off easy enough and the first couple of levels act as tutorials easing the player into the physic-based system of the game. It's too early for me to say how the game pans out, but I think it's hardly going to disappoint from what I've experienced so far. Great characters and enjoyable cut-scenes, I'm genuinely looking forward to spending more time with John Rochard & friends.

Edit:

As it turned out, Rochard was an immensely enjoyable game from start to finish. The game was lean with no padding. Checkpoints were frequent and positioned so there was rarely any grind to get a previous position after dying. The length of the game was also satisfying, never threatening to outstay its welcome.

Playing with a PS3 controller (360 mapped), the controls were very responsive and satisfying. There was also a good balance between combat and physics-based puzzles.

There are Gold badges to collect throughout the game. They don't contribute to any weapon upgrades, etc, but are positioned in the levels to add extra challenge for the obsessive collector. After beating the game, I find I can select individual levels to find badges I've missed which adds to the replay value. I'll probably enjoy playing through Rochard a couple of more times whilst patiently waiting for Episode II.

The developers had an interesting idea here, but I'd say they flubbed on its execution. The game tries to be a mix of puzzle game and platformer, but can't end up doing a very good job of either one. The puzzles are too simple and repetitive when they're present, and the platforming is oftentimes thoughtless. It's not necessarily that either element is too easy, but that they used no imagination in their execution, take no imagination to solve, and generally feel the same throughout the entire game.
The game would have received maybe a 5.5/10 if not for the story. Aside from a horrible case of purple prose and poor dialogue, it packs more cliches than I thought possible and plays them all straight, without any indication that the writers had any awareness of its laughability. The voice acting also really grated on my ears, and the only reason I finished the game is because I kept telling myself it had to get better eventually.
It didn't. I applaud the creators for their work because creating a game is no mean feat, and it took dedication to get this far. But if any of them should happen to read this review, I suggest focusing on one genre and doing it well, rather than trying to combine genres or elements of genres before you've learned what makes either of them work.

Rochard is a sidescrolling platform, action, and puzzle game. You take control of a miner on a distant asteroid that has had little luck finding resources. Your team stumbles upon an important artifact that your boss hurries to investigate when pirates attack and things go awry.

The story is pretty thin, and while they seemed to get the space redneck Rochard just right, some later Native American themes felt pretty out of place. I emphasize the story, setting, and characters so much because that damn theme song sold me so hard. I'm a sucker for space cowboy antics.

Rochard, the protagonist and player-controlled character, uses a mining gun to pull objects close to him, shoot them away, and eventually shoot lasers and bombs. Throughout most of the game, Rochard is able to alter the gravity of the level, which becomes second-nature and part of the player's elegant jumps, swings, and attacks. It's fun to take on enemies by dropping boxes on their heads while leaping gracefully over a platform. There are collectibles for people who want to test the limits of their abilities, too. I didn't bother with every one, but I liked the additional challenges.

This game is kind of like Trine: a platformer with a good amount of fighting and some physics puzzles thrown in. Okay, physics is actually a major gameplay element in fights as well as in puzzle-solving: you get to switch between normal and low gravity, and your main weapon is basically the gravity gun from Half-Life.
The visuals and audio aren't as shiny and rich as Trine, instead going (successfully) for a more clean look and feel. Still, the game features Jon St. John (Duke Nukem!) hamming it up as Rochard, and the main theme is done by Poets of the Fall, and everything fits together quite well, with nothing out of place.
The story doesn't take itself too seriously - suffice to say it's your traditional sci-fi action movie stuff.

And there's just something so satisfying in taking out lots of enemies with what's essentially a power tool while hopping all over the place in low gravity.

Rochard is a simple, yet different kind of puzzle platformer. The twist is, that the main character wields a neat gravity gun, which (besides shooting stuff) allows him to control gravity and lift distant objects.

Each room has a small puzzle or challenge, which needs to be solved before advancing. The puzzles are not very difficult, but are never so patronisingly easy that they ruin the game. Additionally, even if the core concept is simple, they manage to keep it interesting by changing the setting, adding different puzzles (a variety of force fields, low gravity, reverse gravity, electric fields, shielded enemies, improving weaponry with new features etc.).

Speaking of enemies, they can be taken out in a variety of ways, such as dropping heavy stuff on them, pushing them into electric surfaces, manipulating giant mining lasers to cut them into pieces, throwing malfunctioning robots at them, or just plain shooting holes in them.

The story is simple, but the nature of the boisterous main character makes it interesting and fun.

Rochard is just about my favorite puzzle-platformer of all time (though now it has to share that honor with The Swapper).  This game pretty much fell through the cracks when it was released, and it's a shame, because it's a delightful pleasure almost all the way through.  The main mechanic is a special gun which gives the hero (John Rochard, a working-class stiff beautifully voice-acted by Jon St. John) the power to grab things at a distance (like the gravity gun from Half Life 2), control gravity, swing himself into the air, toss people around (eventually) and so on.  The gun also can be used as a gun, and the main weakness of the game is an occasional overreliance on straight combat instead of puzzle-solving.  However, eventually you learn to combine both fighting and environment manipulation while playing, and then the game is serious fun.  It's also light enough and short enough for casual gamers (like me). I wish enough people would play this so we could get a sequel.

A lot of people divide games by pros/cons but that sometimes feels like looking for things to point out that are bad about a game. No game is perfect and I always feel that the number one thing a game should always be is fun, which this one is. However, since this is a review, I'll break it down by different components.

Gameplay: 2D puzzle-platformer that does not treat the gamer like an idiot. You need to actually think on how to solve a puzzle and there are a few different ways to solve each which can be combined with the combat in the game. The puzzle solving and combat can at times go hand and hand which adds a level of difficulty to the game which is all the more satisfying for completing it. The combat itself can be straight forward but that mostly depends on you as a gamer which makes the game feel all the more freeing because you can choose to simply shoot the enemy or figure out a complex way to kill them.

Voice Acting: The cast is small but that is not a terrible thing, Lani Minella who has voiced over 500 animated/video game characters plays Skyler while the main character John is voiced by Jon st. John who is famous for being the voice of Duke Nukem.

Design: The game design can feel almost reminiscent of classic platforming games from the earlier days of video games and that is not a bad thing, the character and level designs are bright and eye catching. John, the main character, isn't your average muscle bound hero, he's an over weight miner just trying to make a living so it's easier to put yourself in his shoes and sympathize with him.

Music: The music is great, though I have a bias since it was composed by Markus “Captain” Kaarlonen from one of my favorite bands, Poets of the Fall, who also composed/wrote music for the game Alan Wake. and had work featured in Max Payne 2.

I would recommend this game and the price isn't that high, considering there are far worse games on Steam asking far higher prices.

Rochard could be described as Half-Life 2's gravity gun in a puzzle-platformer with a slice of action and a sprinkling of metroidvania -- but not entirely, since it's rather linear. A good solid game all around, but short; it took me three hours to complete. Get it while it's on sale and you won't likely be disappointed.

Great game, but the storytelling aims high and falls very short. The gameplay is solid, and the gravity gun mechanic is fun and extremely well implemented. The puzzles are also pretty rewarding, and break up the pace of the game nicely. Unfortunately it ends on a cliffhanger, and it doesn't look like a sequel is coming...

On another note, I found this game to be a great learning tool for the Steam Controller, using the left touch pad as a joystick and the right as a mouse.

I'd recommend picking this up on sale.
